reviews.author: 數學研究生
reviews.title: Interesting Basic knowledge on fixed income and derivatives, Comparison between MATH 4511 and FINA 3203
reviews.comment_content:
I like the content very much, since I like financial maths.

On or before midterm exam:
1. Term structures, spot rates, spot price
2. Bond Valuation, in 4511, Redemption value = Face Value, clean and dirty price
3. Yield rate, annual effective/ nominal, compounded continuously etc
4. Interest rate valuation and bond valuation, modified duration, convexity
5. Floating Rate Bond, Forward rate, FRA and currency forwards.
6. Interest rate swap

After Midterm Exam:
1. Currency Swap, Foreign Currency Swap
2. Options, European and American( just an introduction), call and put, bond call and put option, Put Call Parity and Convexity Property
3. More advanced on options: Callable Bond, Puttable Bond, Caplet, Floorlet, Cap, Floor and Swaption
4. Valuation on European Options: Binomial Tree Models, Risk Neutral Probability, Arrow Security...

As I also study FINA 3203, I will do a comparison.

Similar:
1. Similar syllabus, spot price, forward contracts, FRA, swaps and options and binomial tree model, Arrow Security (also called Binary Options in FINA 3203)
2. Test your brain, e.g. construct arbitrage opportunity, hedge risk

Differences:
1. MATH 4511 teaches caplet, floorlet and swaption while FINA 3203 does not; FINA 3203 teaches futures, American Option (more details), Black Scholes Merton Model, Exotic Options and Credit Spread and Default Probability; I think those things will be covered in MATH 4514.
2. FINA 3203 always assumes interest rate compounded continuously while MATH 4511 does not.
3. FINA 3203 tests more on your Economics knowledge than Math computation, while MATH 4511 tests you more on your brain, or tricks to solve the problems, both courses are very good.

Conclusion: I like both courses, if you want to work on this field in future, you should not miss these two courses. Reminder, Math students should take MATH 4514 instead of FINA 3203/

reviews.comment_content:

Note 1: There are tons of other materials in the course outline (roughly 60% is taught), but there is just not enough time to cover the rest. See the attachment for detailed course outline.

Note 2: Part of this course is aimed for preparing students to take SOA Exam FM (on topic 3: Interest Rate Swaps)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Although attendance is not required for this course, it is beneficial for you to attend his lectures. If you are good at Maths, then the lecture notes itself is sufficient for you to understand the materials (because it is just too neat and good). However, you may need to avoid sitting at the backrow, since you will not be able hear his voice clearly (and you will easily lose focus on the lecture).

*Spoiler alert: If majority of class attend the lecture, then it can almost be certain that your exams are not hard, just the matter of speed );
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Assignments (15% + Mystery Bonus Score)
2. Midterm Exam (25%)
3. Final Exam (60%)

Remarks:
1. As usual, the grading system adopted by Dr. LCM is "absolute grading", in spite of the fact that 117 students are enrolled into this course.

2. There are 3 assignments throughout the term, equally weighted (i.e. each assignment worth 5%).
For assignment 1, there are 60 bonus marks (+5)
For assignment 2, there are 70 bonus marks (+10)
For assignment 3, there are 85 bonus marks (+15)
* You will obtain the bonus marks (in brackets) depending on how much details you provide in each problems, and also on the clarity of the solution.
* If you do all 3 assignment seriously, you can obtain a maximum of 245 bonus marks, which can be used to top-up your midterm score (with 1 midterm score = 8 bonus marks) and also your final score (with 1 final score = 15 bonus marks, if you get 100 in the midterm after the top-up).

3. For the midterm exam, I myself find it quite hard. This is because people who has not learned about "no-arbitrage pricing principle" will find it confusing at first. There are 4 computational questions in the midterm (with 1 harder problem), with 75 minutes allowed.
* The problems are closely related to lecture notes, assignment (especially bonus problem) and problem set. Thus, pay more attention and try to get enough exercise before the exam.

4. Final exam... speed contest! 9 problems, all standard ones, and is basically the same as the midterm. Don't forget to stretch your hand and brain before the exam because it is going to be super TIRING.
reviews.comment_workload:
Basically, you need to put more emphasis on completing the assignments. I myself needed almost 3 days (3 * 9 hours) to complete them. But once you understand how to do the problems in each assignments, then it's just the matter of revision before the midterm and finals.

The workload is big, but it will pay off!

reviews.title: Interesting course on fixed income products
reviews.comment_content:
refer to others' posts
If you have taken MATH 4514 before the course, then pre-midterm content would be easy for you.

However, concepts of financial products related to Black's Model (eg. cap, floor, swaption...) are quite difficult and may need more time to digest.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Wu is a lovely and considerate professor.
He is approachable and helpful in answering your questions after class / via emails or during tutorial sessions. If you feel confused about the concepts, just schedule a meeting with him and clarify your doubts.

I agree that sometimes his lecture notes may jump too fast to the conclusion and students may feel confused. However, it's not a big problem as long as you CLARIFY YOUR DOUBTS with him.

He's an investor in the financial markets as well so he touches on some market events (e.g. FED FOMC, rate hikes, US stock market moves) during classes, too, to give students some color on how macroeconomic policy changes impact the fixed income products + respective hedging strategies.

I think he's underrated... Lol. Perhaps I have a different learning mindset from the others...
reviews.comment_grading:
Very lenient. Many students scored horribly low so Prof. Wu adjusted the grading policy otherwise there would be too many F-grade students.

Many students (like 75%) skipped his classes & tutorials. Only around 20 ppl showed up in his lectures.

I genuinely find fixed-income derivatives (or global markets, generally) interesting so I attended almost every class & tutorial sessions (except those clashing with my superday interviews).

Some exam questions are designed to differentiate A-range students from others with concepts that have been stressed repeatedly in class.


For me:
hw: nearly full marks
midterm: 20/20 (high 20/20, low 4/20, mean 13.2)
final: 38/50 (high 44/50, low 3/50, mean 19.58)

final grade: A+

Not majoring in MATH or MAEC but the course grade was quite good.
reviews.comment_workload:
Fair. The weekly assignments were effective in helping me learn the concepts.

My advice:
ask questions to clarify the concepts or read the textbook (it's available on HKUST library's online access) or Google the concepts

reviews.author: CT
reviews.comment_content: The course covers forwards, futures, options, bonds, bond options, swaps, swaptions etc. Focus is put on calculations of different rates and prices of the above derivatives. Initially the content may look familiar if you have studied financial derivatives before, but the concepts are put into mathematical context (e.g. formulas). It grows a lot more difficult when it goes into topics of rates and bond options. Thorough understanding of the concepts is needed to perform well in the exams, since it involves many proofs rather than plain calculations.
reviews.comment_teaching: Both the powerpoint slides and professor's teaching in class are poorly organized. Most of the time people don't pay attention since the professor speaks at monotone and people find it difficult to understand what he tried to say. No attendance counted so many people did not go to class when the semester reaches its end.

The textbooks can be found online, therefore it is best not to cramp all studying before finals. Can better understand the concepts if start studying early.

reviews.title: 冇想像中咁伏
reviews.comment_content:
Introduction to financial markets

Term Structure of Interest Rate:
>Bonds, bond markets and interest-rate derivatives markets
>Yields, forward rates and swap rates

Mortgage mathematics

Hedging:
>Yield-based risk management
-DV01, Duration and Convexity
-Hedging using DV01 and Duration
>Regression-based hedging
-1-Variable Regression hedging (Hedging 20-year T-Bond with 30-yr T-Bond)
-2-Variable Regression hedging (Hedging 20-year T-Bond with 10-yr and 30-yr T-Bond)

Discrete-Time Models:
>Binomial models for equity derivatives
-CRR Model
>Binomial models for fixed-income derivatives
-Ho-Lee Model
>Arbitrage pricing and the risk-neutral valuation principle

Continuous-Time Models:
>Black-Scholes model and Black-Scholes formula
>Black's model and the Black's formula
>Black formula for caps and swaptions
>Eurodollar futures

Note that Kr01, Caps, Floors is not taught this sem

If you have study MATH2511/4512, the first half of the course is easy. The materials for the term structure of interest rates is just a more detail version in those two courses. In this course, don't expect that the interest is fixed (as this is a fixed income course: By prof.) The interest rate curves are determined by market information (T-Bonds, Zero-Coupon Bonds, Par Bonds and LIBOR).

The second half is much harder than the first part. it takes some time to understand the concepts if you are a MATH student.

Basic Programming knowledge will be expected, Professor will use MatLab to demonstrate some concepts in the second half of this course.

This course is not Math heavy, you just need to have some basic knowledge in probability (CLT, Binomial and Normal Distributions)  and partial derivatives to understand the derivation of the formulae, others are just simply algebras (nothing about matrix operations). Stochastic Calculus is not needed for this course.
